data.name: Disarm Method
data: Rusty chains snake across the ceiling, disappearing into holes on either wall.
Three brass floor plates, nearly invisible beneath the dust and detritus.
An eroded bas-relief of a grinning Pan-like figure, its fingers appear to be moveable.
A shallow gutter runs along the far wall, with a loose brick restricting the flow of water through it.
What appears to be a keyhole is discover behind a loose stone.
A rusted and jammed lever is found beneath a discarded pile of clothing.
A row of fake-emerald buttons on the wall, covered in cobwebs.
Three stones are arranged in a circle on a lead pressure plate.
A painting of an octopus is found in a far corner, three of its arms appear depressible.
A foot-long strip of iron is set into the ceiling, with a small magnet at one end.
A small wooden door opens to a panel filled with strange metal gears.
Three tiny brass levers in a hand-sized hole in the floor.
A moldy rope lies on the floor, leading to a pulley lost in the shadows of the ceiling.
Four keyhole sized openings along the bottom of a door.
A magical rune glows red when touched.
A small statuette of an elephant lies beside a small stone pedestal.
A loose block in the ceiling appears to be hooked to a chain above.
Three counterweights hang on ropes just inside the door.
A bas-relief of a demonic face has depressible eyes.
A camouflaged metal door on one wall conceals a copper lever.
A magic mouth appears and demands a password.
Magic runes spell out “Erase Me” with Read Magic.
A statue of a wizened sage has moveable arms.
An abandoned bottle contains a key matching a concealed hole in the wall.
A loose brick has fallen out of the wall and must be replaced.
A ghostly apparition appears and demands a song be sung to him.
A pulley disarms the trap, but the rope is missing.
A empty gourd hangs from a hook on the wall and must be filled with water.
Three couplets of an old poem are scrawled on the wall; the missing couplet must be recited aloud.
Two orcs are painted on the floor; erasing one disarms, erasing the other sets off trap again.
The trap is not disarm-able, but a detailed schematic of the next trap is drawn in chalk upon the floor.
Four loose bricks must be straitened.
Water must be poured upon a leather strap hanging over the door to loosen it.
A ceramic cap over the disarming panel must be broken open.
A filthy wax seal over the panel must be melted away.
A magic mouth appears and demands to know the meaning of life.
Five pewter runes in the ceiling must be depressed in order.
A console of brass buttons is a decoy; the real trap release is hidden beneath.
Detect Magic must be cast to reveal the invisible lever.
A statuette of a dog must be broken open to reveal a key.
A silver floor panel (20gp value) covers a stone lever crawling with centipedes.
A stone chest must be opened to a precise degree.
An empty hourglass must be filled with sand and turned upside down.
Three wall levers: two set off the trap again, one disarms.
A candle in a wall sconce must be burned down to disarm.
A wall sconce must be turned to a right angle.
A chandelier must be pulled down to floor, revolved 180 degrees, and sent back up again.
Every candle on a seventeen candle-candelabra must be lit; seven candles are missing.
A torch must be applied to a heat-sensitive floor panel.
An invisible statue in the corner must have both arms lowered.
An imp appears and demands payment to disarm the trap.
A globe hangs from the ceiling; Light must be cast upon it.
A hollow needle emerges from the wall; pricking a finger upon it disarms trap.
A ceramic alligator statue with gaping maw: will close maw if fed meat and disarm trap.
A snake-filled pit contains the release lever.
A small ochre jelly (1+1HD) must be coerced off the pressure plate it rests upon.
The open mouth of a gargoyle must be filled with wine or beer.
An illusory wall conceals a control panel.
A release lever at the bottom of a sludge-filled well.
Four small toilets line the far wall; all must be flushed.
A dagger must be placed into the hand of the statue of an impish child.
A complex set of gears is concealed within an armoire.
A lever is hidden behind a wine rack.
An empty, moveable bookcase conceals a set of rope pulleys.
A fake toadstool, among a patch of real ones, may be turned like a doorknob.
A patch of mildew conceals a diagram detailing how to disarm the trap.
An unlit torch on the wall must be lit.
The release lever has a hive of angry wasps built around it.
An acid-filled crystal ewer on a pedestal must be carefully emptied.
A row of clever brass gears is concealed just under the plaster on one wall.
A wick leading into a hole in the wall must be lit.
A row of skulls upon a ledge high on one wall; one contains the detached lever deactivating the trap.
An immense chalk maze drawn into the floor must be carefully walked through to completion.
A magic circle scribed into one wall must have a corpse placed within it.
A blackened steel wire stretches across the ceiling and must be cut.
Forty feet of chain must be pulled from a hole in the ceiling; very noisy (check for wandering monsters).
An iron spike must be pulled out of the stone wall it’s driven into (very difficult!).
A leprechaun is geased to guard the release and must be appeased with gold.
A complex set of archaic runes must be deciphered and read aloud.
A frayed rope pull-cord is concealed behind infested cobwebs.
A nine-headed hydra statue must have its heads hacked off.
Acid must be applied to a soapstone plug.
Seven locks must be picked, or the proper keys found.
A rude drawing of an elven maiden conceals a wall plate.
A magic mouth appears and demands an immediate dance recital.
A shallow pool of filthy water conceals rusty mechanism; must be dry, clean, and oiled.
A brazier must be filled with coal and lit.
A chair attached to a hidden floor lever must be tipped back.
A slimy stone in the wall must be removed, turned, and replaced.
A dagger must be placed into a hole; cannot be removed afterwards.
A hand-shaped depression in the high ceiling must be depressed.
Dust-covered elvish runes on the far wall must be read aloud.
A froglike idol must be knelt in front of, depressing a hidden floor plate.
A rudely fashioned ceramic face on the wall must be broken away to reveal a lever.
Acid must be poured upon a series of thin copper filaments.
Three ceiling hooks must be chained together and pulled; the chain is missing.
The apparition of a pirate appears and demands a bawdy tune.
Three silver wires, nearly invisible, run across the floor from either wall.
Five brass levers are concealed behind the painting of a grinning ettin.
Rows of colored circles dot the floor. A spinning wheel depicts the colors, and hands or feet must be placed on the corresponding colors until the trap releases. May require multiple participants.
